summary:
The story opens by establishing that Jacob Marley, business partner to Ebenezer Scrooge, died exactly seven years ago on Christmas Eve. Scrooge is introduced as an extremely miserly, cold-hearted man who runs the counting house "Scrooge and Marley" with an iron fist, keeping his clerk Bob Cratchit in deplorable working conditions with minimal heat and pay. On this particular Christmas Eve, Scrooge receives visits from his cheerful nephew who invites him to Christmas dinner (which Scrooge rudely refuses), and from two charitable gentlemen seeking donations for the poor (whom Scrooge dismisses with callous remarks about prisons and workhouses). After closing his office and grudgingly giving Cratchit Christmas Day off, Scrooge returns to his gloomy chambers where supernatural events unfold: Marley's Ghost materializes wearing chains made of cash-boxes and ledgers, warning Scrooge that he faces the same fate of eternal wandering unless he changes. Three spirits visit Scrooge on successive nights - the Ghost of Christmas Past takes him through painful memories of his lonely childhood, lost love, and missed opportunities for happiness; the Ghost of Christmas Present shows him the joy and celebration of Christmas throughout London, including the Cratchit family's humble but loving celebration and his nephew's warm Christmas party, while also revealing the wretched children Ignorance and Want as warnings.

The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, a silent hooded phantom, shows Scrooge visions of the future beginning with businessmen on the Exchange discussing someone's recent death with complete indifference, joking about the cheap funeral and lack of mourners. The Spirit takes Scrooge to a wretched part of town where three people - a charwoman, laundress, and undertaker's man - meet at old Joe's pawn shop to sell stolen goods from the dead man, including his bed-curtains, clothes, and even his burial shirt. They mock the deceased for dying alone and unloved, having frightened everyone away in life. Scrooge witnesses the corpse itself lying on a bare, plundered bed in a dark room, unwatched and uncared for. The only emotion the death causes is relief - a young couple celebrates that their merciless creditor has died, giving them hope to escape their debt. In stark contrast, Scrooge then sees the Cratchit household mourning the death of Tiny Tim, with Bob Cratchit showing quiet grief but also gratitude for his nephew's unexpected kindness. As the visions continue, Scrooge realizes the dead man's identity remains hidden as the Spirit leads him toward a churchyard, pointing to a specific grave that will reveal the terrible truth.

people.name: Jacob Marley
people.description: Scrooge's deceased business partner who died seven years ago on Christmas Eve. Appears as a ghost wearing chains made of cash-boxes and ledgers, condemned to wander because his spirit never looked beyond business to help humanity. Warns Scrooge of his fate and announces the coming of three spirits.

people.name: Ebenezer Scrooge
people.description: Formerly miserly, cold-hearted businessman who despised Christmas and treated people with cruelty and indifference. After witnessing his own death and grave through the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come, he desperately pleads for redemption and awakens on Christmas morning completely transformed. Becomes joyful, generous, and kind - sending a turkey to the Cratchits, donating to charity, visiting his nephew, raising Bob's salary, and becoming known as someone who truly keeps Christmas well. Serves as a second father to Tiny Tim and lives as a reformed man.

people.name: Bob Cratchit
people.description: Scrooge's formerly underpaid clerk who worked in terrible conditions, earning fifteen shillings a week with a wife and family. Despite his treatment, maintained Christmas spirit and devotion to his family, especially his disabled son Tiny Tim. After Scrooge's transformation, receives a salary raise and promise of assistance for his struggling family. Scrooge becomes a second father to his son Tiny Tim, who lives rather than dies.

people.name: Scrooge's nephew
people.description: Scrooge's cheerful, married nephew named Fred who visits on Christmas Eve to invite his uncle to dinner and express his love of Christmas despite Scrooge's hostility. Revealed to be the son of Scrooge's deceased sister Fan. Hosts a joyful Christmas party with games and music, showing genuine pity and goodwill toward his uncle. After Scrooge's transformation, warmly welcomes his uncle to Christmas dinner when he unexpectedly arrives.

people.name: Two gentlemen
people.description: Pleasant, charitable men who visit Scrooge seeking donations for the poor and destitute during Christmas season. Initially dismissed rudely by Scrooge, but after his transformation, one of them receives a generous donation from the reformed Scrooge who asks for forgiveness and promises to visit regularly.

people.name: Ghost of Christmas Past
people.description: Strange supernatural figure combining childlike and aged features, with white hair, muscular arms, wearing white tunic with light emanating from its head. Takes Scrooge on journey to revisit his past, including his childhood, sister Fan, apprenticeship with Fezziwig, and broken engagement with Belle. Wrestled with by Scrooge who tries to extinguish its light.

people.name: Ghost of Christmas Present
people.description: Jolly Giant wearing a simple deep green robe bordered with white fur, with bare chest and feet, holly wreath crown, and carrying a torch shaped like Plenty's horn. One of more than eighteen hundred Christmas Present spirits. Takes Scrooge through London and to remote places showing Christmas celebrations everywhere, sprinkling blessings from his torch. Ages rapidly throughout the night and reveals two wretched children - Ignorance and Want - before disappearing at midnight.

people.name: Fan
people.description: Scrooge's beloved younger sister who rescued him from school as a child, telling him their father had become kinder and wanted him home. Described as delicate but with a large heart. Died as a woman after having one child - Scrooge's nephew.

people.name: Mr. Fezziwig
people.description: Scrooge's former master during his apprenticeship. A jovial, generous man who threw wonderful Christmas parties for his employees and apprentices. Wore a Welsh wig and worked behind a high desk. Known for his kindness and ability to make others happy through small gestures.

people.name: Mrs. Fezziwig
people.description: Fezziwig's wife, described as 'one vast substantial smile' who participated joyfully in the Christmas party dancing with her husband.

people.name: Dick Wilkins
people.description: Scrooge's fellow apprentice under Fezziwig, described by Scrooge as being very attached to him. Participated in the Christmas party preparations and celebrations.

people.name: Belle
people.description: Scrooge's former fiancée who broke their engagement because his growing obsession with wealth had changed his nature. A fair young woman in mourning dress who later married another man and had children. Represents the love and happiness Scrooge lost due to his avarice.

people.name: Belle's husband
people.description: Belle's husband who she married after breaking her engagement with Scrooge. Has children with Belle and mentions seeing Scrooge alone in his office with his partner near death.

people.name: Mrs. Cratchit
people.description: Bob Cratchit's wife, dressed poorly in a twice-turned gown but brave in ribbons. Mother to several children including Tiny Tim, Martha, Belinda, and Peter. Maintains household and cooks Christmas dinner. Reluctantly toasts Scrooge's health while expressing her true feelings about his odious character. After mourning Tiny Tim's death in the vision of the future, benefits from Scrooge's transformation as he helps the family.

people.name: Tiny Tim
people.description: Bob Cratchit's youngest son, a disabled child who used a crutch and had his limbs supported by an iron frame. Despite his condition, maintained a cheerful spirit and hoped people would see him in church to remember Christ's healing miracles. The Ghost warned he would die unless circumstances changed. In the future vision, he had died, but after Scrooge's transformation, Tiny Tim lives and Scrooge becomes like a second father to him.

people.name: Martha Cratchit
people.description: Bob and Mrs. Cratchit's eldest daughter who works as a poor apprentice at a milliner's. Arrived late to Christmas dinner after working late the night before and clearing up in the morning. Helps with household duties and tells family about seeing nobility at work.

people.name: Belinda Cratchit
people.description: Bob and Mrs. Cratchit's second daughter, also brave in ribbons. Helps with Christmas dinner preparations, sweetening the apple sauce and changing plates.

people.name: Peter Cratchit
people.description: Bob and Mrs. Cratchit's son who wears his father's shirt collar in honor of Christmas Day. Helps with dinner preparations, mashing potatoes and fetching the goose. His father has a job prospect for him that would pay five shillings and sixpence weekly. After Tiny Tim's death in the vision, reads scripture to the family.

people.name: Scrooge's niece
people.description: Fred's wife, described as very pretty with a dimpled face, ripe little mouth, and sunny eyes. Plays the harp beautifully and participates in party games. Shows some indignation at Scrooge's behavior but joins in the goodwill toward him. Welcomes Scrooge warmly when he arrives for Christmas dinner after his transformation.

people.name: Topper
people.description: A guest at Fred's Christmas party who has his eye on one of the niece's sisters (the plump one with lace tucker). Excellent bass singer who can growl without strain. Pretends to be blind during blind man's-buff but obviously cheats to catch his target. Present when Scrooge joins the Christmas dinner.

people.name: Scrooge's niece's sisters
aliases: the plump one with the lace tucker
people.description: Sisters of Fred's wife who attend the Christmas party. One is described as plump with a lace tucker who becomes the object of Topper's attention during blind man's-buff. They participate in games and express opinions about Scrooge, ultimately solving the riddle that identifies him as the 'disagreeable animal.' Present when Scrooge joins the Christmas dinner.

people.name: Old miner and his family
people.description: An elderly miner living in a hut on a desolate moor with his wife, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. Despite harsh conditions, they gather around a fire for Christmas, singing old Christmas songs together with the old man's voice rising above the howling wind.

people.name: Lighthouse keepers
people.description: Two men who tend a lighthouse on a dismal reef far from shore. Despite the dangerous, isolated conditions with storm-birds and crashing waves, they maintain Christmas spirit, joining hands over their table to wish each other Merry Christmas with grog, with the elder singing a sturdy song.

people.name: Ship's crew
people.description: Sailors on a ship far from shore including helmsman, look-out, and officers. Though described as dark, ghostly figures at their stations, every man hums Christmas tunes, shares Christmas thoughts, or speaks of past Christmas Days with homeward hopes, showing kinder words to each other than any other day.

people.name: Ignorance and Want
people.description: Two wretched, frightful children who emerge from the Ghost of Christmas Present's robe - a boy representing Ignorance and a girl representing Want. Described as yellow, meagre, ragged, scowling, and wolfish, twisted by poverty and neglect. The Ghost warns Scrooge to beware of them both, especially the boy who has 'Doom' written on his forehead.

people.name: Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come
people.description: The third and final spirit, appearing as a solemn phantom draped and hooded in deep black garment that conceals everything except one outstretched hand. Tall, stately, and silent, it neither speaks nor moves but points onward. Shows Scrooge visions of his own death and its aftermath, leading him to his own grave before trembling at Scrooge's desperate plea for redemption and finally shrinking down into a bedpost.

people.name: Businessmen at the Exchange
people.description: Wealthy businessmen who discuss someone's death with complete indifference and callous humor. Include a great fat man with a monstrous chin, a red-faced gentleman with a pendulous excrescence on his nose, and others who joke about the cheap funeral and lack of mourners. Show how unloved and unmourned the dead man was in life.

people.name: Old Joe
people.description: A grey-haired rascal of nearly seventy who runs a pawn shop in the worst part of town, dealing in iron, old rags, bottles, bones, and greasy offal. Sits by a charcoal stove smoking his pipe, buying stolen goods from the dead man's servants with callous indifference.

people.name: The charwoman
people.description: A bold, defiant woman who worked for the dead man and steals his belongings after his death, including his bed-curtains and burial shirt. Shows no remorse, justifying her theft by saying the dead man frightened everyone away in life and deserved no better treatment in death.

people.name: Mrs. Dilber
people.description: The laundress who also worked for the dead man and brings stolen items to Old Joe's shop, including sheets, towels, wearing apparel, and silver spoons. Agrees with the charwoman that the dead man's fate is a judgment upon him.

people.name: The undertaker's man
people.description: Man in faded black who brings modest plunder from the dead man - seals, pencil-case, sleeve-buttons, and a brooch of little value. Less bold than the women but participates in the theft and sale of the dead man's possessions.

people.name: Caroline
people.description: A mild and patient young mother who anxiously awaits news from her husband about their debt. Shows relief and thankfulness when learning their merciless creditor has died, though she immediately prays for forgiveness for the emotion. Represents the only person shown to have any emotion about the death - relief rather than grief.

people.name: Caroline's husband
people.description: A young man with a careworn and depressed face who brings news of their creditor's death. Shows a kind of serious delight which he feels ashamed of and tries to repress. Explains that their merciless creditor has died, giving them hope to escape their crushing debt.

people.name: Boy in Sunday clothes
people.description: A young boy Scrooge encounters on Christmas morning after his transformation. Helps Scrooge by purchasing a prize turkey from the poulterer's shop and arranging for its delivery to Bob Cratchit's house. Scrooge rewards him generously for his service.

people.name: Poulterer's man
people.description: The man who delivers the enormous prize turkey that Scrooge purchases to send to Bob Cratchit's family on Christmas morning. The turkey is described as so large it would be impossible for the bird to have stood on its legs.

places.name: Scrooge and Marley counting-house
places.description: The business office where Scrooge works, kept deliberately cold with minimal heating. Contains Scrooge's office and a small adjoining cell where Bob Cratchit works. After Scrooge's transformation, becomes the site where he playfully tricks Bob about being late before announcing his salary raise and promising assistance to his family.

places.name: Scrooge's chambers
places.description: Gloomy suite of rooms in an old building that once belonged to Marley. Scrooge lives alone here while other rooms are rented as offices. Site of Marley's ghostly visitation and transformed by the Ghost of Christmas Present into a festive grove. Where Scrooge awakens on Christmas morning, transformed and joyful, celebrating his redemption before beginning his acts of generosity.

places.name: London
places.description: The city setting on a foggy, cold Christmas Eve with busy streets, shops decorated for Christmas, and various urban scenes. On Christmas morning after Scrooge's transformation, becomes a place of joy as he walks the streets with a delighted smile, receiving warm Christmas greetings from strangers and finding pleasure in everything around him. Contains the Exchange where merchants gather and various locations Scrooge visits in his transformed state.

places.name: Countryside of Scrooge's childhood
places.description: Clear, cold winter landscape with snow on the ground, featuring fields, a market town with bridge and church, and winding river. Where Scrooge was raised as a boy.

places.name: Scrooge's old school
places.description: Large mansion of dull red brick with broken fortunes, featuring a cupola and bell. Contains a long, bare, melancholy schoolroom with plain desks where young Scrooge spent lonely Christmases reading by a feeble fire. Later deteriorated further when Scrooge grew older.

places.name: Fezziwig's warehouse
places.description: The place where Scrooge served his apprenticeship under Mr. Fezziwig. Featured a high desk and was transformed into a wonderful ballroom for Christmas parties, with dancing, food, and celebration for all employees.

places.name: Belle's family home
places.description: A comfortable room with a winter fire where Belle lives with her husband and many boisterous, happy children. Represents the warm family life Scrooge lost due to his choices.

places.name: Bob Cratchit's dwelling
places.description: A modest four-room house where Bob Cratchit lives with his wife and children despite earning only fifteen shillings a week. Blessed by the Ghost of Christmas Present with sprinklings from his torch. Site of the family's Christmas celebration with goose, pudding, and warm family atmosphere despite their poverty. In the vision of the future, becomes the site of mourning for Tiny Tim's death, but after Scrooge's transformation, benefits from the enormous turkey he sends and his ongoing generosity to the family.

places.name: Desert moor
places.description: Bleak, desolate moorland with monstrous masses of rude stone scattered like a giants' burial place, frozen water, and only moss, furze, and coarse grass growing. Contains a miners' hut where families gather around a fire singing Christmas songs despite the harsh conditions and howling wind.

places.name: Lighthouse
places.description: Solitary lighthouse built on a dismal reef of sunken rocks about a league from shore, surrounded by churning waters, heaps of seaweed, and storm-birds. Despite the dangerous isolation, the keepers maintain Christmas spirit and celebrate together.

places.name: Ship at sea
places.description: A vessel far from any shore on the black and heaving sea where the crew maintains Christmas spirit, with every man humming Christmas tunes or sharing Christmas thoughts and memories of home despite being in the lonely darkness over an unknown abyss.

places.name: Fred's house
places.description: Bright, dry, gleaming rooms where Scrooge's nephew hosts a joyful Christmas party with his wife and friends. Features a comfortable sitting room with fire, lamplight, and space for games. Contains a harp for musical entertainment and has snug corners with chairs and footstools. Becomes the site of Scrooge's reconciliation when he arrives unexpectedly for Christmas dinner after his transformation, being welcomed with tremendous warmth and joy.

places.name: The Exchange
places.description: The heart of London's business district where merchants hurry about, chinking money in their pockets, conversing in groups, checking their watches, and handling their gold seals. Where the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come takes Scrooge to observe businessmen discussing someone's death with callous indifference.

places.name: Obscure part of town
places.description: A wretched area where Scrooge had never penetrated before, with foul and narrow ways, wretched shops and houses, and half-naked, drunken, ugly people. Alleys and archways disgorge offences of smell and dirt, and the whole quarter reeks with crime, filth, and misery. Contains Old Joe's pawn shop.

places.name: Old Joe's pawn shop
places.description: A low-browed, beetling shop below a penthouse roof where iron, old rags, bottles, bones, and greasy offal are bought. Contains heaps of rusty keys, nails, chains, hinges, files, scales, weights, and refuse iron. Secrets are bred and hidden in mountains of unseemly rags, masses of corrupted fat, and sepulchres of bones. Has a parlour behind a screen of rags where stolen goods are examined and appraised.

places.name: The dead man's chamber
places.description: A very dark room with a bare, uncurtained bed on which lies the corpse of the unknown man, covered by a ragged sheet. The body is plundered and bereft, unwatched, unwept, and uncared for. A pale light falls straight upon the bed from the outer air. The room is in a dark, empty house with rats gnawing beneath the hearthstone and a cat tearing at the door.

places.name: Caroline's house
places.description: A modest home where the young mother Caroline lives with her husband and children. The family anxiously awaits news about their debt, with dinner kept warm by the fire. Becomes a place of relief and hope when they learn their merciless creditor has died.

places.name: Churchyard
places.description: A walled-in cemetery overrun by grass and weeds, showing the growth of vegetation's death rather than life. Choked up with too much burying and fat with repleted appetite. Contains the neglected grave bearing Scrooge's own name, where he desperately pleads with the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come for a chance at redemption.

places.name: Camden Town
places.description: The area where Bob Cratchit lives with his family, mentioned when Scrooge arranges for the prize turkey to be delivered there by cab due to its enormous size.

open_threads.description: Supernatural manifestation beginning with Marley's face appearing in the door knocker, followed by mysterious bell ringing and the sound of chains approaching Scrooge's door

Marley's ghost warns Scrooge he will be visited by three spirits on successive nights to give him a chance to escape Marley's fate of eternal wandering. All three spirits complete their visits, leading to Scrooge's complete transformation and redemption
The Ghost of Christmas Past takes Scrooge on a journey to revisit his past, starting with his lonely childhood at school, as part of his spiritual reclamation

The Ghost of Christmas Present appears and takes Scrooge through London and remote places on Christmas to witness universal celebration of the season, revealing the children Ignorance and Want before disappearing at midnight
Tiny Tim's fate - originally sealed to die as the Ghost warned, but after Scrooge's transformation, Tiny Tim lives and Scrooge becomes like a second father to him

The Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come shows Scrooge visions of his own future death, revealing through conversations and scenes that he dies unloved and unmourned. After seeing his own grave and desperately pleading for redemption, Scrooge awakens transformed on Christmas morning and changes his fate completely
